p: Globally viral hepatitis is a leading cause of mortality, with most of the deaths occurring in low and middle-income countries (LMIC) due to hepatitis B virus (HBV) [ 1]. Ambitious global targets have been established to eliminate hepatitis, including a 30% reduction in HBV incidence and treatment of 5 million HBV-infected individuals with antiviral therapy (AVT) by 2020 [ 2]. Along with Asia, Africa has a large burden of HBV, with an estimated 60 million individuals with chronic HBV infection, >95% of whom are undiagnosed [ 3]. Major efforts are underway in Africa to raise awareness and encourage governments to adopt and implement policies that will contribute to global hepatitis elimination. The World Health Organization (WHO) has developed and published HBV treatment [ 4], testing [ 5], and surveillance guidelines for low and middle-income countries (LMIC). The most common AVT for HBV in Africa is tenofovir, an antiretroviral agent used for millions of HIV-positive individuals, which also has high potency against HBV. There is also a rapidly expanding pipeline of new therapeutic agents to achieve HBV functional or virological cure [ 6].
